Situation1: Their partner had a mildly stressful day at work and mentions it casually.
Expectation2: Represent clients effectively in legal proceedings
Situation2: The client’s case involves important disputes that require careful representation
Story: I sat at the kitchen table, my laptop open and legal documents spread out before me. My phone buzzed with a reminder: the client’s hearing was tomorrow, and I still needed to review the latest evidence. Just then, my husband walked in, dropping his bag with a sigh. “Work was a bit much today,” he said, his voice light but his eyes tired. I knew he wanted to talk, maybe just to have me listen and reassure him. But my mind was racing with arguments and case law, the pressure of representing my client weighing heavily on me. I felt the pull—my husband needed my attention, my empathy, my presence. At the same time, my client depended on me to be sharp, prepared, and focused. I could feel the tension building inside, torn between being the supportive wife he deserved and the diligent advocate my client required. My heart ached as I glanced between him and my laptop, knowing I couldn’t give my best to both at the same time.
